Description: Four corroded pieces of a broad knife-blade of very corroded copper: with a tang of square section extending 5.0cm from the butt. The original length of the knife is uncertain, because the front of the blade has been bent back on itself and the metal folded over three times.
Curator's comments: Bibliography; W. B. Emery, W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' III (London, 1958), 50, no. 6 (probably this knife, but as Emery does not illustrate the object it is impossible to be sure). For similar Early Dynastic knives, see W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' I' (Cairo, 1949), 24-30 and pl.9A; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pl.V, 14; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan I and Memphis V' (London, 1913), pl.IV, 1; ; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan' II (London, 1914), pls.I, III, 6; ); J. Garstang, ‘Maḥâsna and Bêt Khallâf’ (London, 1989), pl.XVI, 1-2; Z. Y. Saad, 'The excavations at Helwan art and civilization in the first and second Egyptian dynasties' (Norman, 1969), pl.XVIIa.
Condition: broken into four pieces, one extremely bent
